text:
Eighth Avenue, west side, north from its inception at Hudson Street, showing the triangular Abingdon Square that separates these thoroughfares. Across same is a row of buildings on the north side of W. 12th Street. These will be removed for the new apartment house site identified as No. 299 W. 12th Street. Buildings on the right and beyond the street car, extend from this street to Jane Street. These are to remain.

May 30, 1929

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street, showing in the foreground the Abingdon Square area. The Park identifying same is at the left. In the background, at 14th Street, appears the County Trust Company Building.

View 2 is the same area several years later and showing the new apartment houses that have sprung up around the Square. At the left is the 20 story building, No. 299 W. 12th Street. On the right is the 16-story structure, No. 20 Abingdon Square. On the margin one observes the 6-story residential building that replaced the former Abingdon Hotel (demolished 1931) and adjacent homes.

The last is the latest of all three, having recently been completed. The other two were finished in 1931.

May 27, 1930
May 12, 1940

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street, showing in the foreground the Abingdon Square area. The Park identifying same is at the left. In the background, at 14th Street, appears the County Trust Company Building.

View 2 is the same area several years later and showing the new apartment houses that have sprung up around the Square. At the left is the 20 story building, No. 299 W. 12th Street. On the right is the 16-story structure, No. 20 Abingdon Square. On the margin one observes the 6-story residential building that replaced the former Abingdon Hotel (demolished 1931) and adjacent homes.

The last is the latest of all three, having recently been completed. The other two were finished in 1931.

May 27, 1930
May 12, 1940

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street (left and foreground) showing the Abingdon Square locale and its towering apartment houses. They are the NO. 299 W. 12th Street and the NO. 20 Abingdon Square buildings. Between same appears the County Trust Company Building at 14th Street. In the right foreground is the park that identifies this area. This is triangular in shape and is formed by the convergence of Hudson Street and the beginning of 8th Avenue. The bandstand at the right is on Bank Street. Bleecker Street separates this from the clearance shown. In 1939 a modern 6-story apartment house will rise here, bearing an Abingdon Square address. Views 2 and 3 emphasize the clearance and adjoining structures. Note the absence of the 12th Street building.

Views 1,2: June 18, 1931
View 3: March 9, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street (left and foreground) showing the Abingdon Square locale and its towering apartment houses. They are the NO. 299 W. 12th Street and the NO. 20 Abingdon Square buildings. Between same appears the County Trust Company Building at 14th Street. In the right foreground is the park that identifies this area. This is triangular in shape and is formed by the convergence of Hudson Street and the beginning of 8th Avenue. The bandstand at the right is on Bank Street. Bleecker Street separates this from the clearance shown. In 1939 a modern 6-story apartment house will rise here, bearing an Abingdon Square address. Views 2 and 3 emphasize the clearance and adjoining structures. Note the absence of the 12th Street building.

Views 1,2: June 18, 1931
View 3: March 9, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, north from Hudson Street (left and foreground) showing the Abingdon Square locale and its towering apartment houses. They are the NO. 299 W. 12th Street and the NO. 20 Abingdon Square buildings. Between same appears the County Trust Company Building at 14th Street. In the right foreground is the park that identifies this area. This is triangular in shape and is formed by the convergence of Hudson Street and the beginning of 8th Avenue. The bandstand at the right is on Bank Street. Bleecker Street separates this from the clearance shown. In 1939 a modern 6-story apartment house will rise here, bearing an Abingdon Square address. Views 2 and 3 emphasize the clearance and adjoining structures. Note the absence of the 12th Street building.

Views 1,2: June 18, 1931
View 3: March 9, 1933

P. L. Sperr

Eighth Avenue, (left) east side, north from Hudson Street (foreground), showing the bandstand silhouetted against a new 6-story apartment house. The latter is on Bleecker Street, between the Avenue and Bank Street (right). Irrespective of this, it will bear an Abingdon Square number. To the left is the 16-story apartment house, No. 20 Abingdon Square, located at the S. E. corner of 8th Avenue and W. 12th Street.
View 2 is limited to first mentioned feature. The dark 5-story dwelling at the left is No. 4 Abingdon Square.

P. L. Sperr

May 12, 1940
April 9, 1940

Eighth Avenue, (left) east side, north from Hudson Street (foreground), showing the bandstand silhouetted against a new 6-story apartment house. The latter is on Bleecker Street, between the Avenue and Bank Street (right). Irrespective of this, it will bear an Abingdon Square number. To the left is the 16-story apartment house, No. 20 Abingdon Square, located at the S. E. corner of 8th Avenue and W. 12th Street.
View 2 is limited to first mentioned feature. The dark 5-story dwelling at the left is No. 4 Abingdon Square.

P. L. Sperr

May 12, 1940
April 9, 1940
